choices.choice: He's just started to learn photography.
He is looking at some beautiful pictures.
He is learning art from a professional.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Oh, look at these pictures! They must be the work of a professional! M: You really think so? I'll be happy to tell Phil. But as a matter of fact, he is just a beginner as far as photography goes. Q: What do we learn about Phil from the conversation?

choices.choice: Lend her some money for a cheap apartment.
Move out from the cheap apartment.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: I really need to make some extra money. I've spent my entire budget for the year. W: A cheaper apartment may save you a large amount of money. Q: What does the woman advise the man to do?
M: I think you speak excellent English. Are you from England? W: Thank you, sir, but I'm from Canada. Q: Where is the woman from?

choices.choice: She thought there were no tickets left for the show.
She thought the seats on the left side were fully occupied.
The show was planned a long time ago.
The audience were deeply impressed by the show.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: I heard there are a few seats left for the show tonight. W: Really? I was under the impression that the tickets were sold out a long time ago. Q: What do we know from the woman's reply?

W: Sam, you have been a police officer for thirty years. Then, how do you think of it? M: Well, most people would say that it is very stressful. But to me, patrol is the most stressful one. Q: What is the general picture of being a police officer?

choices.choice: Not as nervous as he expected.

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Were you nervous when the professor called on you? M: I'll say I shook all over. Q: How did the man feel?
M: Wouldn't it have been better to have had Mr. Jones leave at 4 instead of 5? W: Hardly, if we'd had him do that, he would have arrived too early. Q: What did you learn about Mr. Jones?

choices.choice: They had to move her truck.
There was only one thing wrong with her truck.
The engine had to be taken out of her truck.
She had to hire an engineer.

AssessmentItem.Script: M: Why did it take them so long to fix your car? W: Well, for one thing, they had to remove the engine. Q: What does the woman mean?

question.Script: Where does the man want to go?
How much is the train ride?
Where should the man get on the train?
How often do the trains come?

AssessmentItem.Script: W: Excuse me. Do you need any help? M: Nah, I . . . I'm just looking… Um . . . I want to go to the science museum, but I've been lost for the past few hours, and I am not sure how to use these ticket machines. W: Ah, well, just press this button. And from here, it's a dollar fifty. M: Okay. W: Then, get on the train at platform No. 4. M: Alright, thanks, and how often do the trains come around this time of day? W: Usually, they come about every six minutes. M: Okay. And where do I get off the train? W: Get off at State Street Station, three stops from here. M: Okay. I got it. Thanks for your help. W: Not at all. Good luck.

question.Script: What does the man want to buy?

choices.choice: He sent it to others as a present.
It was torn when climbing Mount Tai.
It fell down from Mount Tai.

question.Script: What's wrong with the man's last bag?

choices.choice: It can be used for every purpose.
It has six separate zipped compartments.
It can hold a lot of things.
It is made of artificial material.

question.Script: According to the woman, why is the bag called \"everything bag\"?
How does the man describe the bag?

AssessmentItem.Script: W: What can I show you, sir? M: I had my travelling bag torn when climbing Mount Tai. I want to buy a new one. W: What about this one? People like to call it \"everything bag\". M: Why is it called \"everything bag\"? W: The bag can be used for every purpose. It has six separate zipped compartments, and can hold a lot of things. It is made of artificial material that looks and feels like real leather. M: Really? Will it scuff easily? W: No, it won't. It does not soil easily either and most spots are easy to wipe out. What's more, when the bag isn't used, it can be folded up. M: Great! It is practical and smart. I'll take it.

choices.choice: They will first study the project.
They will dig out the garbage.
They will be divided into teams.
They will pick up litter in the picnic area.

question.Script: How will the club members work to clean up the area?

choices.choice: In a dustbin along the riverside.

question.Script: Where will the club members put litter?

choices.choice: Put them in the plastic bags.
Dig them out and send them to recycling center.

question.Script: What will the club members do with the aluminum cans?

choices.choice: In the shallow waters of the lake.

question.Script: Where will the club members put up the "Do Not Litter" signs?
What is most probably the passage about?

AssessmentItem.Script: Hi, I'm Roris Rily, and I'm the president of the college Environmental Awareness Club. Before we get started, I'd like to thank everyone for coming down to the lake today to help with the cleaning up project. As you probably know, we're going to be cleaning up all of the garbage here at the lake area. We'll begin by dividing into two ten-person teams. One team will pick up litter in the picnic area and jogging trail, and one will dig out garbage found in the shallow waters of the lake itself. We'll be putting the litter in these plastic trash bags. Toss any aluminum cans you find into these boxes, and we'll take them to the recycling center later. A local business has donated these "Do Not Litter" signs to the club. So we'll need a couple of people to place them around the lake when we are through. Ok, everyone who wants to clean up around picnic tables and along the jogging path, raise your hands.

choices.choice: Workers earn more and buy less.
The demand is bigger than the supply.
The demand is smaller than the supply.

question.Script: When do the prices go up according to economists?

choices.choice: We try to earn more money.
We buy less necessities of life.
We learn to spend the money wisely.
We ask the government for help.

question.Script: What do the writer advise us to do when the cost of living rises?

choices.choice: A budget is a list of monthly expenses.
A budget records your income each month.
A budget makes the income meet the cost of living.
A budget lists all daily necessities.

AssessmentItem.Script: Why isn't a dollar worth as much as it used to be? One dollar is always worth the same amount, that is, 100 cents. But the value of a dollar is how much it can buy. The value of money depends on the cost of living. Economists say that the cost of living is the money that a family must pay for the necessities of life such as food, housing or rent, clothes, and medical expenses. For many years now, the cost of living has a low value, you can't buy as many things with it. No one fully understands why the cost of living keeps increasing, but economists believe that workers and producers can make prices go up. As workers earn more money, they have more money to spend, so they demand more goods. If there is a great demand for certain goods, the prices also go up. For example, if everyone wants to buy more and more gas, the price of gas goes up. Families need to know what happens to their money. They need to make their income meet the cost of living, so many people plan a family budget. A budget is a list of monthly expenses. Budgeting helps you spend your money wisely as the cost of living increases.

choices.choice: To improve the secondary education in state schools.
To encourage children to attend secondary schools.

question.Script: What's the purpose of setting up the committee?

choices.choice: Parents whose children will enter state schools.
The children who are at schools.
The teachers at state secondary schools.

question.Script: Which of the following are the representatives of the committee?

choices.choice: The model school will be run by the committee.
The model school is due to open in a year.
The present secondary education in Britain is unsatisfactory.
State schools should be inevitably better than private schools.

question.Script: Which can be concluded from the passage?

AssessmentItem.Script: There has been growing dissatisfaction about the quality of secondary education in state schools. Because of this, many parents have felt a need to educate their children privately, or even educate them at home. The local education authority of a new town in the northeast of England, Compton, has decided to set up a committee composed of representatives of the following groups: the children who attend state secondary schools at the moment, their parents, and the teachers at these schools. The aim of the committee is to decide on the characteristics of a "model" school. The new secondary school which is due to open in Compton next year will be run in accordance with the guidelines drawn up by the committee. Inevitably, there will be disagreement among members of the committee and some kind of compromise will have to be reached.

AssessmentItem.Content: In Jack's country the speed limit was fifty kilometers an hour. Jack often drove (_1_) than that through towns. One day jack was (_2_) his small, red car through a town when a very young policeman (_3_) him and said, "You were driving at more than fifty kilometers an hour, sir. Please give me you name and (_4_)." Jack looked at the young policeman (_5_) and then said to him. "But I started my (_6_) less than an hour ago!" The policeman was (_7_) to his work and did not know the answer to Jack's (_8_). He (_9_) for a few (_10_) and then let Jack go.

In the shoe family, Chinese-style embroidered（刺绣品） shoes, which have been deemed as a perfect combination of the shoe culture and the art of embroidery, are a 100-percent handicraft creation by Chinese people. (_1_) rooted in Chinese culture, they are (_2_) as "Chinese shoes".
In (_3_) China, ever since the matrilineal（母系的） society was (_4_) by a patriarchal（男性主宰的） one, the (_5_) division of labor has been (_6_) on men ploughing and women weaving; the tradition of (_7_) shoes has been passed down from one generation to another (_8_) Chinese women.
Aesthetic（审美的） (_9_), cultural traditions, ethics and morals, as (_10_) as the fashion of different dynasties, have all been well expressed by the needle and thread with which subtle and interesting changes have been incorporated.

Long hours at the screen can cause aching eyes, blurred vision and headaches, experts say. In fact, eyestrain surpasses even wrist pain as the top physical complaint among heavy computer users.
When peering into the computer screen, the eye's focusing muscle is at constant tension. Like any muscle, it feels sore when overloaded. And when someone spends a lot of time looking at something close, the eye muscle can get stuck on the near-focus setting and have difficulty relaxing, leaving the person temporarily nearsighted, a condition called accommodative spasm (痉挛) that can last seconds or hours.
This is why after looking at a monitor all day, some computer workers complain that their distance vision is blurred when they attempt to drive home.
The letters on the screen are not as clearly defined as on a printed page. Take a magnifying glass to your monitor and you'll see the letters, each made up of pinpoint sources of light, have no sharp edges. But those liquid crystal display (LCD) monitors, like those found on laptop computers, are easier on the eyes because they display sharper images.
And studies have shown that when people are working on a computer, their rate of blinking goes down by two-thirds, which can result in dry, stinging eyes. This is especially a problem for contact-lens wearers.

question.prompt: ___ used to be the biggest physical problem that computer users had.
Working hours before the screen will _____.

choices.choice: impose too much burden on the eye’s focusing muscle
make it difficult for the user to learn driving
magnify the letters on the screen

question.prompt: LCD monitors are better in terms of eye protecting because ___.

choices.choice: they will not blur the user's eyes
they bring about no eye problems
they display letters with sharp edges

question.prompt: Dry, stinging eyes are caused by ___.

choices.choice: lower rate of blinking of the computer user's eyes
letters on the screen without any edges

question.prompt: Which group of people are most likely to get dry, stinging eyes?

AssessmentItem.Content:
The next time someone receives an award as an outstanding teacher, take a close look at the reasons given for selecting that particular person. Seldom is it because his or her students did higher quality work in math or spoke better English or in fact had any accomplishments that were better than those of other students of teachers who did not get an award.
If your criterion for judging teachers is how much their students learn, then you can end up with a wholly different list of who are the best teachers. Some of the most unimpressive-looking teachers have consistently turned out students who know their subject far better than teachers who cut a more dashing figure in the classroom and receive more lavish praise from their students or attention from the media.
My own experience as an undergraduate student at Harvard was completely consistent with what I later learned as a teacher. One of my teachers — Professor Arthur Smithies — was a highly respected scholar but was widely regarded as a terrible teacher. Yet what he taught me has stayed with me for more than 40 years. Nobody observing Professor Smithies in class was likely to be impressed by his performance. He sort of drifted into the room, almost as if he had arrived there by accident. During talks, he often paused to look out the window and seemingly became fascinated by the traffic in Harvard Square.
But Smithies did teach us. He got us to think — often by questioning us in a way that forced us to follow out the logic of what we were saying to its ultimate conclusion. Often some policy that sounded wonderful, if you looked only at the immediate results, would turn out to be counterproductive if you followed your own logic beyond stage one. Arthur Smithies would never get a teaching award by the standards of the education establishment today.

question.prompt: Which one of the following is a possible reason why some teachers are awarded as outstanding teachers?

choices.choice: Their students do higher quality work.

question.prompt: Which one of the following is the most decisive in choosing the best teachers?

choices.choice: How well their classes are received.
The criterion used for judging teachers.

question.prompt: Which of following is NOT true about the author?

choices.choice: The author was once an undergraduate student at Harvard.
The author believes teachers who cut a dashing figure in the classroom are always good teachers.
The author believes teachers should not be judged only by the praise they receive from the students.
widely regarded as a good teacher

question.prompt: Why does the author say Professor Arthur Smithies would never get a teaching reward?

choices.choice: Because today's selection standards only focused on the immediate results.
Because he was widely regarded as a terrible teacher.
Because his classroom performance was not satisfactory.
Because he questioned the students and forced them to think on their own.
